title: Kamer Qaka
text:
Kamer Qaka (born 11 April 1995) is an Albanian professional <a href="association%20football">footballer</a> who plays as a <a href="Midfielder%20%28association%20football%29%23Defensive%20midfielder">defensive midfielder</a> for Hungarian club <a href="Mez%C5%91k%C3%B6vesdi%20SE">Mezőkövesd</a>.
Club career.
Early years / Norway.
Qaka was born in <a href="Peja">Peja</a>, modern-day <a href="Kosovo">Kosovo</a>, but when he was two years old his family moved to <a href="Norway">Norway</a> and settled in <a href="Brandbu">Brandbu</a>. In 2010, while still attending <a href="Secondary%20school">lower secondary school</a>, he signed his first professional contract for Norwegian <a href="Eliteserien%20%28football%29">Eliteserien</a> side <a href="V%C3%A5lerenga%20Fotball">Vålerenga</a>.
In a May 2010 <a href="2010%20Norwegian%20Football%20Cup">cup</a> game against <a href="Oppsal%20IF">Oppsal IF</a>, as Qaka made his professional debut, he became Vålerenga's youngest goalscorer ever. He made his league debut in 2011.
In 2013, he signed for fellow Norwegian club <a href="Raufoss%20IL">Raufoss</a>. He made his debut on 15 April 2013 against <a href="Odds%20BK">Odd 2</a> as they won the game 2-1. In January 2014, he joined <a href="H%C3%B8nefoss%20BK">Hønefoss BK</a>, and a year later he went on to <a href="Sarpsborg%2008%20FF">Sarpsborg 08 FF</a>.
In 2016 he tried his luck with <a href="Kristiansund%20BK">Kristiansund BK</a>. His performances paid off when Qaka helped his team get promoted to the <a href="Eliteserien">Eliteserien</a>, as well as being awarded the trophy for the best player in the league.
Politehnica Iași.
On 17 July 2017, after terminating his contract with Kristiansund, Qaka put pen to paper on a two-year deal with Romanian team <a href="FC%20Politehnica%20Ia%C8%99i%20%282010%29">Politehnica Iași</a>. A week later, he made his competitive debut in a 0–0 <a href="Liga%20I">Liga I</a> draw with <a href="CS%20Gaz%20Metan%20Media%C8%99">Gaz Metan Mediaș</a>, coming on as a half-time substitute for <a href="Dan%20Sp%C4%83taru%20%28footballer%29">Dan Spătaru</a>. From the following matchday, Qaka established himself as a starter under head coach <a href="Flavius%20Stoican">Flavius Stoican</a>.
In November 2017, after his international debut for <a href="Albania%20national%20football%20team">Albania</a>, it was reported that fellow league teams <a href="FC%20Steaua%20Bucure%C8%99ti">FCSB</a>, <a href="CFR%20Cluj">CFR Cluj</a> and <a href="CS%20Universitatea%20Craiova">Universitatea Craiova</a>, as well as Portuguese side <a href="S.C.%20Braga">Braga</a>, were interested in acquiring the player.
Universitatea Craiova.
On 3 June 2019 he signed a 4-years contract with <a href="CS%20Universitatea%20Craiova">CS Universitatea Craiova</a>.
International career.
Qaka from 2010 until 2014 has been part of <a href="Norway">Norway</a> at youth international level, respectively has been part of the U15 and U19 teams and he with these teams played 36 matches, he accepted the invitation from the <a href="Albania%20national%20football%20team">Albania national team</a> by coach <a href="Christian%20Panucci">Christian Panucci</a> for the <a href="Exhibition%20game">friendly match</a> against <a href="Turkey%20national%20football%20team">Turkey</a> on 13 November 2017 as a replacement for the injured <a href="Amir%20Abrashi">Amir Abrashi</a>. He debuted for Albania against Turkey as a 67th minute substitute for <a href="Odise%20Roshi">Odise Roshi</a> in a 2–3 away win for his side.
